<p>
[<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=hec" rel="me">MR. CLAY</a>] TO <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=ftb" rel="colleague friend met">FRANCIS BROOKE</a>. 
</p><p>
 <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=washington" rel="city">Washington</a>, March 4,  <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1825">1825</a>. 
</p><p>
My dear Sir, I have the gratification to tell you that all my 
information from the West bespeaks a satisfied state of the public mind, in relation to the result of the late election. In Ohio 
the approbation of it is enthusiastic. In Kentucky, too, the expression of public opinion evinces general acquiescence. 
</p><p>
I transmit to you, inclosed, two letters, which are from <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=jjc" rel="colleague met">Crittenden</a> and <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=wic" rel="colleague met">Creighton</a>, two of the most discreet men in Ohio and 
Kentucky. Be pleased to show them to Mr. Pleasants. 
</p><p>
[<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=hec" rel="me">Henry Clay</a>]
</p>
